titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for Carol June Bradley Papers, circa 1900-2010 (bulk, 1960-1999)
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by John Bewley.

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library.

did.abstract: Contains the extensive research papers of music librarian Carol June Bradley, including biographical information about fifteen American music librarians, files compiled in preparation of her history of music libraries in the United States, documents pertaining to the history of the Music Library Association, teaching materials used in courses in the Music Librarianship graduate program at the University at Buffalo, collected writings by other authors about librarianship, a bibliography of song literature for singers, her research about song literature, and her personal, business-related correspondence.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Specified item], Carol June Bradley Papers, circa 1900-2010 (bulk, 1960-1999), Music Library, The State University of New York at Buffalo.

accessrestrict.head: Terms of Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials can be examined by qualified researchers in the Music Library during hours of operation during which Music Librarians are present. In order to insure access, researchers are advised to contact the Music Library in advance of visits.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Copyright for the materials in the collection does not reside with the Music Library. Therefore, patrons wishing to publish any item, or part of an item from this collection for any purpose, are responsible for securing requisite permissions.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Carol June Bradley. The bulk of the collection was donated in 1978 but additions continued until Bradley's death.

accruals.head: Accruals and Additions
accruals.p: No further accruals are expected to this collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Carol June Bradley was born 12 August 1934 to George and Alice (Bolinger) Bradley in the central Pennsylvania town of Huntingdon. Her family later relocated to Carlisle, Pennsylvania. Bradley demonstrated her writing ability while still a high school student when she won first prize in the Lamberton Essay contest with her essay about the Irving Female College. She attended Lebanon Valley College in Annville, Pennsylvania to major in music education, graduating in 1956. However, she did not have a positive reaction to her student teaching experience, and with advice from a school librarian in Carlisle, decided to attend library school at Western Reserve University. She earned her M.S. degree there in 1957. During her college years Bradley also studied violin, attending summer sessions at Chautauqua Institute where she studied with Hortense and Mischa Mischakoff. She continued her education with a Ph.D. program in Library Science, earning the degree in 1978.

Bradley began her career as a music librarian in 1957 at the Free Library in Philadelphia where she was responsible for the Drinker Library of Choral Music. She wrote a history of the Edwin A. Fleisher Music Collection at the Free Library that served as her M.S. thesis in library science at Western Reserve University. Bradley left Philadelphia in 1959 to accept a new position at West Point Military Academy. Her tour of duty at the academy was brief but distinguished. She established a music library and also conducted a regular series of recorded concerts and pre-opera seminars. She left in 1960 to join the staff of the music library at nearby Vassar College. This began her long association with James B. Coover and provided her with the years of experience in technical services that shaped much of her later scholarly work.

The George Sherman Dickinson Music Library at Vassar College used Dickinson’s own classification scheme for its music collection. Bradley became the leading authority on this classification system and later adopted it for use at the University at Buffalo. She wrote and published the chief guide to the system in 1968: The Dickinson Classification: A Cataloguing and Classification Manual for Music.

Bradley moved to Buffalo in 1968 to begin work as the associate director of the newly established University at Buffalo Music Library, reporting once again to James B. Coover who was hired as director. Both Coover and Bradley remained in their positions until retirement in 1999. As adjunct professor at the University at Buffalo, Bradley, with James B. Coover, co-founded and co-directed a double master's program in music librarianship. She was instrumental in designing and administering the rigorous program that successfully trained a new generation of skilled music librarians.

Carol June Bradley conducted groundbreaking and extensive research into the history of music libraries and music librarianship in the United States. Her first work based on this was her doctoral dissertation, The genesis of American music librarianship, 1902-1942 (1978). Other works about music librarianship included American music librarianship : a biographical and historical survey (1990) and American music librarianship : a research and information guide (2005).

The excellence of Carol June Bradley's work as researcher and teacher was recognized by the State University of New York when she was awarded the Chancellor's Award for Excellence in Librarianship in 1977. The Music Library Association presented its highest award, the MLA Citation, in recognition of Bradley's many contributions to music librarianship in 2001. At its 2003 annual meeting, MLA announced the establishment of the Carol June Bradley Award for Historical Research in Music Librarianship, an annual award to support studies that involve the history of music libraries or special collections; biographies of music librarians; studies of specific aspects of music librarianship; and studies of music library patrons' activities. The first award was granted in 2004.

In retirement, Bradley completed two life-long projects, an annotated bibliography of the field of American music librarianship (American Music Librarianship: A Research and Information Guide [New York: Routledge, 2005]) and her 1,008-page index to song collections (Index to Poetry in Music: A Guide to the Poetry Set as Solo Songs by 125 Composers [New York: Routledge, 2003]). Carol June Bradley died in Buffalo, New York, 27 July 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Contains the extensive research papers of music librarian Carol June Bradley, including biographical information about fifteen American music librarians, files compiled in preparation of her history of music libraries in the United States, documents pertaining to the history of the Music Library Association, teaching materials used in courses in the Music Librarianship graduate program at the University at Buffalo, collected writings by other authors about librarianship, a bibliography of song literature for singers, her research about song literature, and her personal, business-related correspondence. The collections consists of manuscript, print and photocopied content, with photocopies constituting approximately one half of the material.

The collection includes a series of papers from librarian Richard Sloane Angell regarding the Music Library Association and his unpublished text,
Music Library Organization. Bradley also assembled a collection of correspondence concerning Otto Kinkeldey.

The original catalog description of the collection was stated as: "Collected correspondence, memoranda, writings and other papers, of American music librarians; together with research notes, tapes and transcripts of interviews, and photos, document1ng the history of American music librarianship and the activities of the Music Library Association. Persons represented include Otto Edwin Albrecht, Richard Sloane Angell, Richard Gilmore Appel, Lowell Pierson Beveridge, Gladys Chamberlain, Virginia Meeks Cunningham, George Shennan Dickinson, Carl Engel, Jessica Fredricks, Otto Kinkeldey, Catherine Nimitz Lay, Natalie Mestechin, Philip Lieson Miller, Eva Judd O'Meara, Elizabeth Schmitter, Carleton Sprague Smith, Oscar George Theodore Sonneck, Harold Spivacke, and Edward Neighbor Waters."

The bulk of the collection was received in 1978. A description entry was created for the National Union Catalog of Manuscript Collections under the title Collection of source materials documenting the history of music librarianship in the United States, 1901-1979, Carol Bradley, collector. The same title was used for an entry in Resources of American Music History. Access to the collection content was provided through an inventory, Guide to the Collection of source materials documenting the history of music librarianship in the United States. That guide is now obsolete, replaced by the current finding aid. The order presented in that guide, along with its descriptions, has largely been maintained.

As originally constituted, the collection also contained the cassette sound recordings of the interviews conducted by Carol June Bradley. These recordings now form a separate collection, Carol June Bradley Music Librarianship Oral History Recordings, 1973-1988.

Over the remainder of the course of Carol June Bradley's career at the University at Buffalo Music Library (until her retirement in 1999), more material was added to the collection, and due to the vagaries of shifting the materials multiple times, it became more difficult to maintain the original source materials as a collection distinct from Bradley's other research materials. Therefore, all of Carol June Bradley's papers are now combined within this single collection. The original order of the collection was chiefly maintained even when it resulted in similar content, such as writings by other authors, being treated in separate series. Folder titles assigned by Bradley were also retained. Dating of materials at the series and box levels will be supplied at a later date.

item.ref: IV. History of music libraries in the United States
VI. Music librarianship articles by others
XI. Collected publications and research sources

scopecontent.p: Includes vitae, obituaries, business correspondence (most of it written on her behalf for work issues), awards, and clippings.

Contains:
Authority and democracy, responsibility and professionalism: an outline
Bibliography for singers (with notes and search results)
Cataloging and classifying music
Genesis of American music librarianship, 1902-1942: a prospectus
Music in American libraries: outline
Music libraries, in Women in music in America since 1900
The Music Library Association, 1931-1981
Oscar G. T Sonneck, architect of the National Music Collection, in Libraries and culture (1981)
Reader in music librarianship: original bibliography
Towards an automated record catalogue: a description of the system used at The State University of New York at Buffalo

Contains:
Documentation: Bibliographic development in music
Manual of music librarianship (annotated copy with typescript index, accompanied by folder of reviews)
Music Library Association's Manual of music librarianship (typescript with editing marks)
Manual of music librarianship
Music libraries in North America (photocopy of typescript with corrections)
Music libraries in North America (photocopy of pages 356-426 in Encyclopedia of library and information science, v. 18

Contains:
Compilation of cataloging guidelines for University at Buffalo Music Library
Dickinson classification: a cataloging and classification manual for music (with annotations)
State University of New York at Buffalo Music Library Subject headings (unattributed but presumably compiled by Bradley)

did.unittitle: Personal writings, part 4: research and writings on the Edwin A. Fleisher Music Collection

scopecontent.p: Includes Carol June Bradley's 1957 paper, A history of the Edwin A. Fleisher Music Collection of the Free Library of Philadelphia, multiple versions of Harry L. Kownatsky's The Edwin A. Fleisher Collection of Orchestral Music: a history, documents from the Free Library of Philadelphia, photographs, and Bradley's editing copy of Kownatsky's text.
Contains folders of content pertaining to the history of music librarianship in the United States. It has been treated as received, using the original organization and folder titles.
Content includes correspondence, material related to interviews conducted with the subjects, and supporting materials.

did.unittitle: Albrecht, Otto to Dickinson, George Sherman

Fd. 5. Positive photocopies of correspondence re Vassar College and the Music Library Association catalog code, 1935; originals in the MLA Archive, University of Maryland, College Park.
Fd. 6. Positive photocopies of Dickinson's published writings: articles and reviews; laid chronologically.
Fd. 7. Offprints of Dickinson's published writings.
Fd. 7A. Offprints of Dickinson's published writings.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog.

list.head: Works by Carol June Bradley
list.item: American Music Librarianship: a Biographical and Historical Survey. New York: Greenwood, 1990
American Music Librarianship: a Research and Information Guide. New York: Routledge, 2005.
Anna Harriet Heyer: An Isolated Pioneer. In Notes 63.4 (2007): 798-805.
Documentation: Bibliographic Development in Music, 1970.

Biography of George Sherman Dickinson ; Biography of Otto Kinkeldey ; Biography of Oscar George Theodore Sonneck. In Dictionary of American Library Biography. Littleton, Colo.: Libraries Unlimited, 1978.

Classifying and Cataloguing Music in American Libraries: A Historical Overview. In Cataloging and Classification Quarterly 35.4/5 (2003): 467-481. And In Historical Aspects of Cataloging and Classification. The Haworth Press, Inc. 2003: 467-481.

The Dickinson Classification: A Cataloguing and Classification Manual for Music. Including a Reprint of the George Sherman Dickinson Classification of Musical Compositions. Carlisle, Pa.: Carlisle Books, 1968.
The Dickinson Classification for Music: An Introduction. In Fontes Artis Musicae 19 (1971/72): 13-22.
Eastman's Ruth Watanabe. In Notes 62.4 (June 2006): 904-925.
Edward N. Waters, notes of a career. In Notes 50.2 (1993): 485.
The Genesis of a Music Library: SUNY at Buffalo. (with James Coover) In Notes 57.1 (Sept. 2000).
The Genesis of American Music Librarianship: 1902-1942. Thesis (Ph.D.). Florida State University, 1978.
A golden celebration: the Music Library Association, 1931-1981, The Music Library Association, 1981.
A History of the Edwin A. Fleisher Music Collection of the Free Library of Philadelphia. Thesis. Western Reserve University, 1957.
Index to Poetry in Music: A Guide to the Poetry Set as Solo Songs by 125 Major Song Composers. New York: Routledge, 2003.
Irving Female College, 1953.
Kownatsky, Harry L. The Edwin A. Fleisher Collection of Orchestral Music: A History. (Manuscript edited by Carol June Bradley), 2008.
Manual of Music Librarianship. (Edited by Carol June Bradley) Ann Arbor: Music Library Association, 1966.
MLA Summer Meeting of 1949? Notes 36.3 (March 1980).
Music Collections in American Libraries: a Chronology. (Compiled by Carol June Bradley.) Detroit: Information Coordinators, 1981.
Music libraries in North America. In Encyclopedia of Library and Information Science, v.18. New York: M. Dekker, 1976: 358-425.
The Music Library Association: the Founding Generation and its Work. In Notes37.4 (1981): 763.
Notes of some pioneers: America's first music librarians. In Notes. 43.2 (1986).
Organising music in libraries. II: Cataloguing. In Cataloging and classification quarterly. 1.2-3 (1982): 141.
Reader in Music Librarianship. Washington: Microcard Editions Books, 1973.
Richard S. Hill: Tributes from Friends. (Co-editor with James Coover) Detroit: Information Coordinators, 1987.

Towards an Automated Record Catalog: A Description of the System Used at the State University of New York at Buffalo: Exhibits Illustrative of the outline. (Prepared by Carol June Bradley for June 28, 1973, Music Library Association, Las Vegas, Nevada), 1973.
Vassar's Music Library: the First Hundred Years. Notes 35.4 (1979): 819-846.
William Lichtenwanger, reference librarian. Notes 62 (Dec. 2005): 299-321.
William J. Weichlein: an appreciation. In Notes 51.4 (1995): 1254.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p:
The following titles were removed from the collection:
Brook, Barry S., editor. Musicology and the Computer: Musicology 1966-2000: A Practical Program. New York: City University of New York Press, 1970.
Bryant, E. T. Music Librarianship: A Practical Guide. London: James Clarke, 1959.
Coover, James. Basic concepts and practical steps in building a college music library. In College Music Association, Ninth Annual Meeting, 1955.
Coover, James. A bibliography of East European music periodicals. In Fontes musicae, 1956-1962.
Coover, James. Gesamtausgaben, a checklist. Distant Press, 1970.
Coover, James. Medieval and Renaissance Music on Long-Playing Records. Detroit: Information Service, 1964.
Coover, James. Reference Bibliography in the Music Library. In Library Trends, Aril 1960.
Crawford, Richard, and Wiley Hitchcock. The Papers of Andrew Law in the William L. Clements Library. Ann Arbor, 1961.
Davis, Donald G., editor. Libraries and culture. University of Texas Press, 1981.
Hopkinson, Cecil. A Dictionary of Parisian Music Publishers, 1700-1950. London, 1954.
Kent, Allan, editor. Encyclopedia of Library and Information Science, volume 18. New York: Marcel Dekker, 1976.
Library of Congress. Manuscript Division. Hugh Lafayette Black: A Register of His Papers in the Library of Congress. 1982.
Library of Congress. Manuscript Division. The La Follette Family: A Register of the Papers in the La Follette Family Collection in the Library of Congress. 1981.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Resources in the Music Library

defitem.label: Carol June Bradley Music Librarianship Oral History Recordings, 1973-1988Mus. Arc. 76
defitem.item: Recordings of interviews with 37 music Librarians from various institutions in the United States to research the history and practices of music librarianship.

defitem.label: Otto Kinkeldey Papers, 1898-1962Mus. Arc. 54
defitem.item: Contains offprints of articles by Otto Kinkeldey and others, correspondence, documents related to the Committee on Graduate Study in Music (1938), Kinkeldey's transcriptions of musical works, and one of his own compositions.
